messages.title: Our children deserve better than the Tories' failure on education
messages.content: Class sizes are soaring despite the Tories' promises to keep them down. Over half a million children are now taught in super-sized classes.

keyPolicies.policyDescription: Class sizes are soaring despite the Tories' promises to keep them down. The number of unqualified teachers is rising under the Tories, with an increase of 52 percent since 2012, with standards falling as a result. Schools are having to make £3bn worth of cuts by 2020, hitting standards further as they are receiving less to do more. Just paying for the basics. The Tories have now announced that they would scrap universal free school lunches for infant school children.

issues.education: Class sizes are soaring despite the Tories' promises to keep them down. Over half a million children are now taught in super-sized classes. The number of unqualified teachers is rising under the Tories, with an increase of 52 percent since 2012, with standards falling as a result. Schools are having to make £3bn worth of cuts by 2020, hitting standards further as they are receiving less to do more. Just paying for the basics. The Tories have now announced that they would scrap universal free school lunches for infant school children.

examples: Over half a million children are now taught in super-sized classes.
The number of unqualified teachers is rising under the Tories, with an increase of 52 percent since 2012.
Schools are having to make £3bn worth of cuts by 2020.
The Tories' School Report: Class sizes - FAILED, Enough qualified teachers - FAILED, Funding schools properly - FAILED, OVERALL - FAILED
Our children deserve better than the Tories' failure on education.
A vote for Labour on Thursday, 8 June is a vote against cuts to local schools.

Class sizes are soaring despite the Tories' promises to keep them down. Over half a million children are now taught in super-sized classes. The number of unqualified teachers is rising under the Tories, with an increase of 52 percent since 2012, with standards falling as a result. Schools are having to make £3bn worth of cuts by 2020, hitting standards further as they are receiving less to do more. Just paying for the basics.
Class sizes are soaring despite the Tories' promises to keep them down.
The Tories have now announced that they would scrap universal free school lunches for infant school children.
